Netliner, I worked on the same wonderful NY Times exercise you recall, and it took me less than an hour to figure out how to eliminate the federal deficit within 10 years using the same strategies you did, and without cutting Social Security, Medicaid, or Medicare.
The People's Budget introduced by the Congressional Progressive Caucus in April 2011 likewise would eliminate the federal budget deficit over 10 years without cutting these entitlements. It takes the same approach that Netliner and I did with the NY Times exercise.
Mr. Keller, I don't object to discussion of trimming entitlements as one among many policy options for the country to consider.
But I object strongly to columns like yours claiming that there's no way to get the federal budget deficit under control without cutting entitlements. That canard is flat-out wrong, and you do a terrible disservice to your readers when you perpetuate it.

Hey, I remember that (even at my age) ! I also remember that I solved the federal deficit ( as did, probably, many others) with just a handful of small, pragmatic, common sense  changes to various programs. Oh, and the "boomer" thing...I don't recall getting any handouts, but i do expect to get social security (although it does need to be tweaked for the future).

The problem with eliminating the ceiling on SS taxes is simple. Each additional dollar collected in excess of outgoes is simply put in the general fund and spent each year. This will leave an enormous unfunded payout ahead; one which will truly break SS.

The answer is not bashing the Boomers, it's enacting better public policy.

A couple of years back, this newspaper ran a wonderful interactive, online feature that allowed readers to attempt to balance the federal budget deficit over a 10-year period. Numerous policy options were given and the budgetary assumptions were drawn from the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office.

I recall that I eliminated the 10-year federal deficit largely by sharp cuts in military spending, the return to Clinton-era tax rates, the closure of diverse tax loopholes, and by eliminating the ceiling on incomes subject to Social Security withholding. These are policy actions well within our grasp.

Additional cost saving measures are also possible in the area of health care. The introduction of a public option for health coverage would substantially reduce the administrative costs of health care delivery, as would instituting incentives that would reward health care providers for using best practices that would enhance patient care while reducing expenses.

Let's press for solutions, not cast intergenerational stones.

The Salton Sea is an unearthly place. It's like you're in a Ray Bradbury story--a failed earthling colony on another planet, with its bar, its grocery store, its hopeful street signs, all in the midst of a deeply alien landscape that is the combination of desert basin and agricultural-waste pollution. It's alluring in a lot of ways--the kind of people who dug dead factories twenty years ago would relate, but there's also the deep pull of the desert all around. Joshua Tree is just over there to the east. At the same time quite a lot of it is unutterably depressing--see the hamlet of Bombay Beach, and those reeking dead fish don't help either. And then there was that failed Hollywood plan to build a new Tahoe there in the '50s--but enough. This unbelievably dim scheme is just another chapter in a whole book of idiocy appertaining to and touching on that remarkable place.

Alexander, Thank you so much for your kind words and encouraging story.  My daughter is so happy to hear about the successes of other people with Asperger's.  And as you say with love and encouragement, she will flourish.

Reading this article brought back my own adolescent memories. I also have Asperger's syndrome (AS), am a recent college grand and still recall fondly the struggles and quirks of growing up in a "normal" world. For me, it was a war of my parents knowing that I could go out into the world with no problems while I was a little afraid to and yet sometimes very eager too. Having grown up in the suburbs and finishing high school in Upstate New York, I found the smaller school environment (a K-12 student body of not even 900) a better fit than a suburban school. But each individual with AS is different, and that should be accounted for.

Riley-Hall's article was a phenomenal read, especially as her author's page has her from New York, so it's comfort knowing that. I've spoken on behalf of a professor of special education (at my college, which is known for it's teaching programs) about what it is like having Asperger's. I tell these future teachers to not have the students feel excluded from regular classroom activities, and for parents to let their special needs child take on a challenging endeavor. If a teen with AS wants to enroll in an AP class in high school, and if they are mature enough to handle it, then by all means let them. Given the right encouragement, assistance and environment, a teen with AS can flourish. AS might be a challenge, but it's surely not a death sentence.

Actually, Florida does have a competitiveness problem, if what I have seen and read is correct. The New Yorker Magazine did a piece a couple of years back which stated that an extraordinarily high percentage of the adults living in Florida hold real estate licenses. This shows, among other things, that there isn't much else to do there besides sell houses to newcomers and sell services to tourists. It is a state built on dreams, illusions and sunny days rather than substance and industrial productivity of any sort. The housing bubble started in Florida and when it burst, the results hit the state with a very hard thud.

Virtually none of our states could stand on their own if they were modest size independent nations. Texas? Highly dependent on the federal govt. for agricultural subsides, defense expenditures and favorable tax treatment for the oil business. States like Pennsylvania and Ohio might have a fighting chance, because they still have a good deal of manufacturing. California, because of the size of its economy, might also be a candidate to survive on its own.

Those who complain constantly about the role of the federal govt. should remember that the amelioration of state and regional differences (conflicts) is part of what makes us successful. Without some successful balancing of regional needs and wants, the whole American enterprise would fly off into space like parts of a collapsing space station.

This is the typical shortsightedness of the Indian health ministry.First of all, the country spends less than 3% on health care.There is just no modern infrastructure for training in the government medical colleges where the majority of aspiring doctors train.As a result the overall level of training has enormous gaps.This is the reason that you will see most of the "Indian" ministers going overseas for their healthcare.They all know how bad the situation is.

The problem is then worsened when you send these doctors to the rural area.We used to have to depend on drug reps to supply basic medicines.You get a sense of total helplessness as you are hardly able to treat anything serious and most doctors there are quickly looking for a way to set up private practice where they can make more money.

The third problem is post graduate training.The world has moved toward specialty training as each field within medicine has expanded tremendously.As a result, the MBBS model,set up by the British is obsolete and the primary care doctor will get paid peanuts unless they slog away at their own private practice for at least 8-10 years.Even private hospitals do not increase the pay for MBBS doctors with increasing experience and they remain,forever, as RMOs (Residential Medical Officers) --a junior doctors post.The government has not increased the number of post graduate trainee spots because they are still stuck in the old model.In addition, barring a few "institutes of excellence" most of the so called "academic" centers in India do not offer additional facilities for post-graduate training.

The only tool left in the US power structures tool box is the US military. As the old saying has it "If all you have is a hammer, ever problem look like a nail."

In an effort to recover from its decline US imperialism has launched itself onto a course of military aggression that will end in a terrible and costly tragedy for the American people and the world if not reversed.

The decision by the US power structure to try to organize a war party against China may backfire as both India and Japan may have other ideas as to what may be best for their own future survival at a time of great international stress bought about by the present global crisis of capitalism and the decline of US imperialist empire.
